Yoritaka	1	.	Saku; Hashiri-kani; Nikiri-kani	figure	location	Japan	.	lactea	Yamaguchi2001.1	"Female crab, originally drawn by Kurimoto Suiken. Saku = &ldquo;running crab&rdquo;; Hashiri-kani = &ldquo;running crab&rdquo;; Nikiri-kani = &ldquo;fist crab&rdquo;"	"A natural history manuscript edited by Matsudaira Yoritaka, with figures by many different artists. The date of completion is uncertain, but is after 1762, while Yoritaka died in 1771. Included are a few figures of the fiddler crab <em class=""species"">Uca lactea.</em>"

Suiken	1	.	Tenbo-gani; Shiomaneki	figures	location	"Wakayama, Japan"	.	arcuata	<	Three different figures of male crabs. Tenbo-gani = &ldquo;one handed man crab&rdquo;; Shiomaneki = &ldquo;tide beckoning crab&rdquo;	"This is the general collection of the drawings of Suiken. The dates are unknown, but much of it has to predate 1826, since figures from this collection were reproduced in the <em>Kai-ka rui siya-sin<em> which was given to Siebold in that year. Three of the four fiddler crab drawings (all <em class=""species"">Uca arcuata</em>) were reproduced in the later work."	
Suiken	2	.	.	figure	location	Japan	.	arcuata	<	"A male crab, not reproduced in the later work."	.	
Suiken1826	1	Ocypode (Gelasimus)	Kometsuki-gani; Shiomaneki	plate 2: figure 11	citation	Yoritaka	1	=	=	Female crab. Kometsuki-gani = &ldquo;rice-cleaning crab&rdquo;; Shiomaneki = &ldquo;tide beckoning crab&rdquo;	"This is the collection of drawings given by Suiken to Siebold in 1826. Most, if not all, of the drawings were reproductions from earlier works, some of which were by other artists. Of the five fiddler crab illustrations in this manuscript, at least four are originally by Suiken (the male <em class=""species"">Uca lactea</em> may not be).<p>The Japanese names are from Suiken; Latin names, when given, were added by Siebold.<p>These were used, in part, by de Haan when describing the Japanese Crustacea."

MilneEdwards1837.2	4	Gelasimus forceps	Gélasime pince	text p. 52	specimen	Australasia	.	?	.	"(Crane, 1975: p. 323) This name has been discarded. The ""male"" specimen turns out to be an amalgamation of a female body from one species (identifiable only to subgenus <em class=""species"">Tubuca</em>) and a claw from a male <em class=""species"">Uca lactea</em>. Another specimen stored nearby, labeled as ""lactea"", turned out to be a claw from a male <em class=""species"">Tubuca</em> on a male <em class=""species"">U. lactea</em> body. While it is likely the claws can be swapped, we still have a minimum of 3 different individuals in this mixup, including a male claw and female body, possibly, but not definitively from the same species. "	.

Smith1870.2	1.1	Gelasimus styliferus	.	"text p. 114-115, 118-119"	location	Ecuador	.	stylifera	<	.	"Smith may be the first author to formally discuss splitting fiddler crabs into broad- and narrow-front groups, although he does not name them (different names are not applied to these groups until Bott 1954). He also recognizes complete distinctness between the American Atlantic and Pacific species."

Nutting1919	1	Uca leptostyla	.	text p. 182	location	"Antigua, Antigua and Barbuda"	.	burgersi	>MSR	"A strange typo mixing up multiple names. The author refers to figures from Rathbun (1918) and was clearly not attempting to create a new name. While geographically, it could be a reference to <em class=""species"">Uca leptodactyla,</em> Rathbun (1921) later identifies a few specimens from the same expedition as <em class=""species"">U. mordax,</em> although we now know that the correct identification for Rathbun's specimens should be <em class=""species"">U. burgersi.</em>"	.
